subject: linear_algebra
title: Solving Systems of Linear Equations
contentHtml: Solve systems of linear equations in matrix form using Gaussian elimination.
name: System of Linear Equations" },
solutionHtml:
We can solve this system using Gaussian elimination:

  • First, we'll add -2 times the first equation to the second:
    • \[\\mathbf{A}x = \\begin{bmatrix}1 & 2 \\\\ 3-6 & -1+4 \\end{bmatrix}\\[0.5em]x = \\begin{bmatrix}4\\\\0\\end{bmatrix}\]
  • Now, we can see that the second equation is already satisfied:
    • \[\\mathbf{A}x = \\begin{bmatrix}1 & 2 \\\\ 0 & -3 \\end{bmatrix}\\[0.5em]x = \\begin{bmatrix}4\\\\-1/3\\end{bmatrix}\]
",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Add -2 times the first equation to the second", "mathHtml": "\\[\\mathbf{A}x = \\begin{bmatrix}2 & 1 \\\\ 2-2 & 3+2 \\end{bmatrix}\\[0.5em]x = \\begin{bmatrix}4\\\\-3\\end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "This eliminates the second variable."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Add -1 times the first equation to the second", "mathHtml": "\\[\\mathbf{A}x = \\begin{bmatrix}2 & 1 \\\\ 0 & 4 \\end{bmatrix}\\[0.5em]x = \\begin{bmatrix}4\\\\-3/2\\end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "This eliminates the second variable."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Write down the solution", "mathHtml": "\\[x_1 = 2, x_2 = -1/2\\]", "explanation": "The solution is now clear."} ],
intuition: Gaussian elimination helps us solve systems by transforming the matrix into upper triangular form.
visualDescription: A diagram showing the row operations and resulting matrices
commonMistakes: Forgetting to check for singular matrices

subject: linear_algebra
title: Solving Systems of Linear Equations
contentHtml: Solve systems of linear equations in matrix form using Gaussian elimination.

problem.solutionHtml: To solve this system, we'll use Gaussian elimination.

steps.description: Rearrange the matrix to have a leading one
steps.explanation: This makes the next step easier

steps.description: Use row operations to eliminate the top-left entry
steps.explanation: Now we can focus on the bottom row

intuition: Gaussian elimination helps us transform the matrix into upper triangular form, making it easier to solve.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Solving Systems of Linear Equations
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to solve a system of linear equations using matrix form.

hints: Hint: Use row operations to transform the matrix
problem.solutionHtml:
To solve this system, we'll first convert it into matrix form:

  • \[ \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 & -1 \\ -1 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 1 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ -1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \]

steps.description: Add the first two equations to eliminate y
steps.explanation: This step helps us get rid of the y variable

steps.description: Add the resulting equation to the third equation
steps.explanation: This step helps us get rid of the z variable
Now we can solve for x and then substitute back into the original equations to find y and z

intuition: The key insight is that row operations allow us to manipulate the matrix without changing its solution.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Solving Systems of Linear Equations: Matrix Form
contentHtml: Solve systems of linear equations in matrix form using Gaussian elimination.

hints: Hint: Use row operations to transform the matrix
problem.solutionHtml: To solve this system, we'll use Gaussian elimination.

steps.explanation: This is the standard form for a system of linear equations.

steps.description: Apply row operations to transform the matrix
steps.explanation: We're using row operations to eliminate the variable x_2.

steps.description: Simplify and solve for the variables
steps.explanation: We've simplified the matrix and can now solve for the variables.
The solution is the values of the variables x_1 and x_2.

intuition: Gaussian elimination helps us solve systems by transforming the matrix into upper triangular form.
